Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: Bug casting String, Integer, Double using HashMap: :I have some strange bug on Android 2.3 and lower.I have following code:HashMap<Somekey, Object> data = new HashMap<Somekey, Object>();data.put(somekey, "asdfdsafdsf");String value = (String) data.get(somekey);on the last line I have ClassCastException: get(somekey) returns Boolean value instead of String. Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: Bug casting String, Integer, Double using HashMap: :I have some strange bug on Android 2.3 and lower.I have following code:HashMap<Somekey, Object> data = new HashMap<Somekey, Object>();data.put(somekey, "asdfdsafdsf");String value = (String) data.get(somekey);on the last line I have ClassCastException: get(somekey) returns Boolean value instead of String. This error appears not only with String type, with Integer and Double too.I don't understand why, because this code correctly works on android 4.0.3 and higher.
Please using this api: Map.get.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Map.get
<<<code>>>: HashMap<Somekey, Object> data = new HashMap<Somekey, Object>();
data.put(somekey, "asdfdsafdsf");
String value = (String) data.get(somekey);
<<<explanation>>>: The get() method of the Map interface returns the value to which the specified key is mapped, or null if this map contains no mapping for the key.
Question: How can I get the current date and time in Java?
Please using this api: LocalDateTime.now.
Answer:<<<api>>>: LocalDateTime.now
<<<code>>>: LocalDateTime now = LocalDateTime.now();
<<<explanation>>>: The now() method of the LocalDateTime class returns the current date-time using the system clock and the default time-zone.
Question: How can I get the current date in Java?
Please using this api: LocalDate.now.
Answer:<<<api>>>: LocalDate.now
<<<code>>>: LocalDate now = LocalDate.now();
<<<explanation>>>: The now() method of the LocalDate class returns the current date using the system clock and the default time-zone.
Question: How can I get the current time in Java?
Please using this api: LocalTime.now.
Answer:<<<api>>>: LocalTime.now
<<<code>>>: LocalTime now = LocalTime.now();
<<<explanation>>>: The now() method of the LocalTime class returns the current time using the system clock and the default time-zone.
Question: How can I get the current time in milliseconds in Java?
Please using this api: System.currentTimeMillis.
Answer:<<<api>>>: System.currentTimeMillis
<<<code>>>: long currentTimeMillis = System.currentTimeMillis();
<<<explanation>>>: The currentTimeMillis() method of the System class returns the current time in milliseconds.
